cs351.project1

Class SpatialHashMap

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs351.project1.SpatialHashMap
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Collection<Actor>>

    public class SpatialHashMap
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Collection<Actor>>
    Citation: http://www.gamedev.net/page/resources/_/technical/game-programming/spatial-hashing-r2697 A spatial hash map is used to divide some space into a series of buckets in order to better decide which objects are close to each other. For example, if you have a grid that is 500 pixels by 500 pixels and a tile width/height of 50 pixels, this class will create a spatial hash map that is 10 buckets by 10 buckets. In order to decide which bucket(s) an object goes in, the hashX and hashY functions are used. These functions convert an (LOCATION_X, LOCATION_Y) coordinate into a hashed pair representing an index into a 2D array of buckets. From there the ending LOCATION_X and LOCATION_Y are calculated by adding the object's width and height (converted to tiles) to the hashed (LOCATION_X, LOCATION_Y) coordinate pair.
    Author:
    Justin Hall

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.util.Collection<Actor>> iterator()
        Iterates over the buckets and returns the actors they contain.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Collection<Actor>>
        Returns:
        iterator over collections of actors that are close by each other in space

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Wipes all buckets.

      • insert

        public void insert(Actor actor)
        Calculates the starting bucket and ending bucket in 2-dimensions and places the actor into *ALL* the buckets it overlaps with. Even if it only overlaps a bucket by 1 pixel it is placed into that bucket as it might potentially collide with other actors in that bucket.
        Parameters:
        actor - actor to insert
